critique: This document pertains to the Selective Service Act during World War I. It aims to balance military needs with the necessity of maintaining essential civilian functions by carefully managing exemptions from the draft. The document emphasizes the importance of national defense and efficient operation of government services during wartime. It also stresses fairness and discourages favoritism in granting exemptions. There is no direct mention of immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The document seems to expand executive power to ensure the draft operates effectively. The federal government takes primacy over state control. The document does not seem to have a strong ideological tilt. It is focused on national security and the efficient operation of the government during wartime. There is no economic regulation mentioned.
